Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

At the APCI Escambia Plant liquid hydrogen is stored.  Some of the compounds handled are considered hazardous by EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  We insist on strict adherence to safety precautions developed to prevent human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal safety and health, as well as the safety and health of our coworkers and minimize the threat to our community and the environment.  Our safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the proper maintenance of the safety systems designed in these facilities, the procedures used by our personnel and the training of these personnel.  

At the APCI R&D Pilot Plant facility, Epichlorohydrin is received via tank truck in 37,000-lb increments, and off-loaded, with vapor return to the truck, into three 1500-gal, 304 stainless steel, 150-psig storage tanks with fire-proof insulation.  The headspaces of these tanks are kept bottled up with a nitrogen blanket.  The epichlorohydrin is fed directly from each of these tanks, one at a time, to a continuous reactor train at <0.2 GPM, where it is reacted with an alcohol to <0.5% epichlorohydrin.  All feeds are controlled by state-of-the-art feed and temperature control systems.  Product is transferred to check tanks before being stored in a 2500-gal tank.  The stated maximum inventory of epichlorohydrin is 40,000 lbs. 

Our safety programs are modeled after the ACC?s Codes of Responsible Care.  Our emergency response plan, which is based on OSHA?s HAZWOPER regulation, contains procedures for notification of the local Emergency Management Authority, local fire department, and potentially affected neighbors.  Neighbor notification can take the form of an automated telephone ring down system, sponsored by local industry.  The telephone system is augmented by a network of sirens surrounding the plant site, which can be activated by eith

er Emergency Management or Plant personnel.     
                                                                       
This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Plan regulation (40CFR, Part 68). The substances and processes considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the regulation.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

This Liquid Hydrogen Storage facility stores and ships liquid hydrogen.  The R&D Pilot Plant facility stores Epichlorohydrin, and reacts it to make an alcohol adduct. 

The regulated substance handled at the Liquid Hydrogen Storage facility is hydrogen which is labeled as a "Flammable Substance" by EPA.

The regulated substance handled at the Pace R&D facility is Epichlorohydrin which is labeled as a "Flammable Substance" and ?Toxic Substance? by EPA.


The General Accident Prevention Program and Specific Program Steps

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation. This facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes. 

Five-year Accident History

Within the past five years there have been zero incidents that would be reported under RMP.

The Emergency Response Program

 APCI contracts Emergency Response services from Taminco Methylamines Inc. which shares the site with APCI.    The site's emergency response program is based on OSHA's HAZWOPER standard. At this site, employees are trained to recognize emergencies and initiate emergency response from outside agencies. All employees have been trained to OSHA's First Responder Awareness Level. The site also has a fire and emergency services crew, who are trained to the HAZMAT Technician or HAZMAT Specialist levels of the OSHA's HAZWOPER standard. All employees receive annual refresher training in the emergency plan. Emer

gency response activities have been coordinated with the Santa Rosa County Emergency Management Agency and the Pace Volunteer Fire Department. Periodic drills are conducted with these agencies to review the effectiveness of our emergency plans. The last drill was held with the Santa Rosa County Emergency Management Agency on 10/28/2004. Monthly planning and communications meetings are held with the Santa Rosa County EMA.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Plant hazards reviews, risk analyses or incident reviews are among the systems we rely on to drive safety improvements. At this time there are no major administrative, operational, process of equipment changes planned for the Liquid Hydrogen Storage facility or the R&D Pilot Plant facility.
